I would like to recommend NOT using the super shuttle services, at least not in paris where we used them and were very disappointed .
My wife and I pre-ordered the super shuttle services online .
When we landed yesterday in paris , we called them and they said they will dispatch a shuttle right away and it will arrive in 5 minutes .
If we would have known we at least would have had the option to decide whether we want to stay and keep on waiting or leave earlier with another company or service .
Another family with kids that waited with us , finally decided to quit and left after half an hour .
If I had known that this is the type of service that we will receive I would never have booked them from the beginning .
I 've used shuttle services many times in in Paris to\/from CDG and Orly , and have never had a problem .
One bad experience does not a bad company make .
I just came back from Paris two days ago and had used Super Shuttle .

I prebooked but found upon landing that due to construction at the terminal and waiting forever on the phone to reconfirm from baggage claim that it was very confusing  and I work as a flight attendant so am used to European limo services on a regular basis .
I finally got a ride from them only after an hour and then waiting for another 20 minutes while they picked someone else up at another terminal .
The return ride was prompt however we stopped to pick up several other people so an extra 45 minutes were added on to my original pickup time of 630am .
I think that if you are traveling as a single it is more economical but if there are more than two traveling just take a taxi .
My friend and I are flying -LRB- hopefully first class -RRB- from Florida to Florence and returning from Rome .
We 're closer to Ft. .
Lauderdale , but Miami ok .
Do n't want to make more than 1 stop .
You are n't going to find direct flights from either airport .
Fort Lauderdale represents itself as an international airline , but it 's mostly to Central and South America .
Miami will have more options .
Only one airline flies nonstop to Rome , which is Alitalia .
The Florence airport is a regional airport .
You 'll find lots of international flights going to from Bologna , then a short train ride down to Florence .
Try asking on the airlines board .
Use Change Forum above .
Also not every airline flies a first class .
Some max out at Business .
Your best bets are Lufthansa or Swiss .
Both offer 1-stop flights to Florence or Rome from Miami , both offer first class , and both have superb F products .
I prefer Swiss 's inflight first class , but Lufthansa 's F ground services are probably the best of any airline , anywhere .

My husband and I have never used a travel agent before -LRB- aside from work travel -RRB- and have generally been happy and excited to plan our own travel .
However , now that we have kids , we do n't have the time to do lots of travel planning so we 're considering using a travel agent .
We do n't want to do group tours but are mainly interested in having someone help plan a rough agenda for us , book hotels , car rentals\/car services , etc. .

Does it make sense to work with local travel agents in the country we plan to visit , realizing we 'd have to find new agents each trip or should we find a US-based agent and work with them on an on-going basis ?
Any advice or tips are appreciated !
We use a US based Travel Agent who has helped us plan several trips all over the world .
He 's associated with Virtuoso Travel a world wide association of over 7200 agents in 20 countries and calls upon `` experts '' in the different countries we visited to help plan itineraries .
He 's helped put together some very special and detailed trips for us .
A god travel agent gets to know you , your likes and dislikes and can tailor a trip to meet your specific needs .

Now , we make basic travel plans such as trips to see relatives and shot vacations to places we are familiar with , on our own but when we want something special , including trips to new countries or complex trips that include numerous travel legs , private tours , speciality hotels\/resorts , etc then we definitely use our Travel Agent .
So , check around and find yourself a professional TA who does more than just book hotels .
Sounds to me like a TA shill .
Only post , period .
Because Fodor 's is a website specifically designed for and frequented mostly by self-planners , you do n't usually get much feedback about the `` using a travel agent '' type questions .
To me , SnappyGo looks like a nice in-between a full-service travel agent and doing it yourself .
I believe it 's fairly new and I 've never tried it myself , though .

I usually buy a SIM when I get in Country but if you 're hopping around Europe you have to get one in each Country or pay the roaming rates on the one you 've got when get to a new Country .
But when your SIM runs our of credit you ca n't buy more credit for it in another country , so you 'd have to get a new one .
They have multi-country SIM cards that work everywhere .
I have a National Geographic one , but the rates on it are n't as good as local Country SIMs , but you do n't have to keep switching .
I 'll gladly pay the prevailing rates for long distance not to carry a cell phone with me .
The point of going on holiday is just that , a holiday from the everyday world .
One does not need instant communication 24x365 .
I run from the thought of that happening to me .
EU Law dictates that you ca n't be charged xxx amounts of money while roaming ... That being said , I 've had good coverage with O _ニ___ , owned by Telefonica .

I have heard bad things about their customer service  indeed , in their case , I should n't have to pay to call their customer service , yet I do , but still , you do n't pay for calls received , just made.

The worst thing would be to try and top up what they call refilling your credit with notes , since they only take British Credit\/Debit Cards when topping up by phone , since more than likely , you 'll be on prepaid .
They usually include x amounts of minutes to a select number of countries , the US included when I was there last in July ' 11 , they had like 100 minutes included when I topped up # 15 .
Also , if you 're going to be in London , do n't forget to get a Transport for London Card .
Even if you 're going to be there a few days , it does save some money and you can use it on the Tube and iconic Double Decker Buses .

I have read that someone simply used a plastic bag from the grocery store and put holes in it in order for the water to drain out , which sounds like the easiest way out ; but , I 'd like to bump it up a notch or two if at all possible .
I like to take along my own facial cleanser , shampoo , and soap .

I 've read about one cruiser who brought along an inexpensive over-the-door shoe bag to hold all the toiletries , but what about something to use IN the shower to avoid leaving containers on the shower floor ?
I generally travel with those wonderful gadgets with suction cups but am not sure of the surface of the shower walls from ship to ship .
A grocery bag seems a little icky to me .
I 'd use the suction-cup thing .
I 've never encountered a shower stall in a cruise ship that was n't smooth enough to hold one of the suction cups .
There may be exceptions , though .
It 's not a very busy forum , but I 'd also post this on the Cruise forum .
Frequent cruisers may be able to help , and there are some there .
I think the cruise shower caddy by Favors By Serendipity is perfect .
I also like the soap pocket on a rope and their luggage tag holders .
I agree , post on the Cruise forum , hardly anyone reads this `` Travel Tips '' branch .
I have a number of small plastic mesh bags with a drawstring similar to this : http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-AmlzVCxXDKs/TGJYOV-o51I/AAAAAAAAASI/cyV53ccSFUc/s1600/mesh.jpg
Instead of a plastic grocery bag , you could hang one or more of those on a suction cup hook .
A fabric mesh bag , like you use for lingerie in a washing machine .
How long are you traveling for that you can not live without a shower caddy ?
However , I 'm glad it did because I 've always found it a pain being in a shower that did n't have shelving .
You have to worry about your soap dish filling with water and bending down to pick up stuff which is sometimes awkward depending on the size of shower.
A mesh bag and suction cup take up so little room that I 've added them to my toiletries kit .
Until this thread came up , I would n't have thought of bringing something to keep my shower items off the floor .
So , even if I was going only overnight , it 's worth it to me .
It 's not a matter of the length of the trip IMO .
I have experimented with various travel things that had a suction cup attached , but found , for whatever reasons , I kept leaving them in the hotel room .
My all time favorite item , an unbreakable 10X mirror , 4 inches in diameter which sticks right onto the big mirror for putting on mascara or contact lenses I have replaced no less than thrice .
So a shower caddy would only be good for one trip for me !
For some reason my eyes do n't see things on vertical surfaces when I scan the room to see if I 've forgotten anything .
I have a hanging , multipocket mesh organizer which has a hook to hang it from the shower head arm .
I think I bought it at a dollar store .
It works very well .

I just want to let everybody know about the Worldwide Survival Conference , an event being hosted by S4C - The Sri Lanka Community Centre Construction Corps - A UK-based charity aiming to raise funds to build a large community center in Matale , Sri Lanka to provide jobs and facilities for victims of the 2004 Asian Tsunami who are still suffering in from the fallout of the disaster , most of whom are living in a nearby Red Cross-run refugee camp .
A must attend Conference for anyone who wants to gain more Confidence , learn new ways to look after themselves , colleagues , family and friends at travel or work anywhere in the World .

The Worldwide Survival Conference offers an all-day event from 10am to 6pm , with tea , coffee and a buffet lunch , a fun day and several useful and interesting seminars for the frequent traveller or tourist , whether on or off-the beaten track including :
Tips and advice for working and traveling in remote areas , by veteran globe-trotter Mark Callow of GOMAD .
Dealing with major wounds and injuries
By the British Red Cross
Personal protection , Self defense and bodyguarding family and friends
by Clive Whitworth of the Intensive Training Group
Use of basic weapons to protect yourself against knife or machete attack
by Gary Alderman European Escrima\/Kali and Stick fighting champion Gary Alderman
There will be an exhibition of guns , weapons and mines from all over the world and a Specialist to give you information on how to disarm them and their properties .
Also Julie Thompson from Bedford Hypnosis and NLP will be there to give you some tools to help prepare yourself for a Crisis or conflict and cope with Post Incident Stress .
There will be time for questions and answers with the experts after the talks and demonstrations .
More details and ticket booking can be found at http://www.eventbrite.com/event/2816021797
Also more information on S4C and it 's mission can be found at www.SriLanka4c.com

Do not buy what your company offers almost always more costly
has saved my posterior times Iceland Volcano especially .
You want company with AM Best A rating only .
I `` self-insure '' plane and hotel costs .
I generally self-insure tours , in the rare cases I take one , although Rick Steves ' tours include cancellation\/interruption insurance in the price .

If you could n't afford to `` eat '' any costs for travel or accommodations that you could n't cancel without penalty you should consider insurance , but read the conditions carefully and do n't buy from an outfit that is providing the service you 're covering .
I make sure my medical insurance covers me abroad.
if you are a US senior be aware that Medicare does not -RRB- , but ALWAYS take out medical evacuation insurance .
Lately I 've been dealing with Seven Corners for that .
What kind of insurance do you want ?
I paid less than $ 200 for medical and trip cancellation insurance to cover the prepaid costs of this trip with TravelSafe , purchased through www.squaremouth.com .
We were reimbursed $ 250 per person to change our tickets as well as a $ 350 copay per person for one way upgrades to Biz Class on American and $ 150 pp to redeposit the miles for the upgrade .
All we had to do was provide the required documentation and an Attending Physician 's Statement and received a check within a couple of weeks .
I guess we could have `` self insured '' but we 'd have been out $ 1300 .
We 've taken trip insurance for our last 4 trips due to the advanced age of my mother in law and the fact that we are n't getting younger either .
Sure enough , in 2010 my husband came down with pancreatitis and we had to postpone our European trip .
And , since my mother in law is still with us at 90 yrs old , we will continue to take out insurance on future trips .
It gives us peace of mind which is why you get insurance in the first place .

I agree that if you are going to insure your trip , you need to look at the risk vs. cost - how much money would you lose if you canceled and are you ok with that , versus how much the insurance would cost .
For me , the math has n't worked out - we have never prepaid enough to warrant buying the insurance .
We do buy a travel medical plan because our primary medical does n't cover us out of the country .

Yes exactly that , but the hand luggage has to be a backpack or similar .
Trolley cases can not fit in overhead compartment , of bus .
Some people had them on our tour , because they had not received their tickets and tour info , till it was almost time for departure .
Their bags went in with the suitcases , so they did not have access to them , whilst we were on the `` road '' .
The size restrictions are all listed in the Insight brochures .
`` Remember a tour is not a vacation , it is a tour ''
I have a 4 wheeled walker with a seat and hand brakes that I use when I have a lot of walking to do .
We are doing the Country Roads of Switzerland Sept. 19th .
I was wondering how many cobblestone streets there would be and if putting the walker on the trains would be a problem .
I also will have my cane along for times when the walker wo n't really be practical .
I have not done the CR of Switzerland - have done CR of France , Ireland and Italy but I think that you may find that you are limited in what you can do and where you can go .
In the 5 tours that I have done , I can only remember one lady with a walker and I do recall she was limited in her activities - spent some time in a cafe instead of exploring .
I 'm not sure if that was her or the walker that needed a break .
They were all however limited to where they could go as many of the old buildings we visited did not have lifts and had a lot of stairs .
On one trip there were five ladies who were not able to walk up hills so the tour director had to order two taxis for them as they could not all fit into one .
This was done at their own expense as Insight does not pay for this .
It worked out quite epensive in the long run as this was the Country Roads of Italy tour where there were a lot of hills to walk up .
The ladies did however enjoy the tour and did see as much as was possible because the tour director was very , very helpful .
The lady on the mobility scooter unfortunately missed out on quite a lot , this was an Easy Pace Tour of Italy two years ago .
There were problems with being able to charge up the mobility scooter , so she was stuck with not being able to walk .
Lenore , I have not done the tour you are doing , but I have done a lot of tours with Insight .
I have been on tours where there have been people with wheelchairs , walking canes , one lady even had a mobility scooter .
I do hope that all goes well for you , I have to say that I admire anyone who has the desire to travel , regardless of their mobility issues .
All the best to you .
Life 's a journey not a destination - Aerosmith , Amazing
The problem there was the speed of the tours .
I 'll be sure to take along my seated cane for when there are a lot of stairs .
Thank you for your input .
I did the Country Roads of Italy and Sicily , but used my cane .
I need to sit quite freqently so could n't keep up .
I can do the stair and use the cane for assistance and sitting at the top .

Be aware that hotel wireless might not always work on your smart phone .
It might be good to travel with a small laptop or do research on your phone 's specifications before you leave .
Although technologies change very quickly , it would have been good for us to know some of the issues that could arise before we departed on our trip .
In our trip to Italy over the past 3 weeks , at 2 of our 5 hotels we were unable to log in to the hotel 's free wireless service using our HTC Desire Android phones purchased in North America .
The wireless network did not even show up as an available network in our hotel room .
However , in both cases we WERE able to access the wireless network from our room using our laptop computer .
Luckily we could set up a tethering system by plugging our phones into the laptop one by one , using its internet connection .
The problem may be due to the signal strength demanded by the phone 's wireless system -LRB- compared to the computer 's -RRB- , and walls could get in the way and reduce signal strength .
Some hotels had an internet wireless connection for each floor of the building .

In one hotel we could access the wireless network directly by phone only when sitting on a chair in the ground-floor hallway next to the room that broadcast the wireless frequency ; anything farther away would lose connection .

However , at this same hotel , when in our room our phones detected secure networks for nearby hotels across the street -LRB- it was in downtown Florence -RRB- and our laptop could access the wireless network .
The hotel staff said that they have occasionally encountered this issue with guests ' smart phones .
It was nice that they supplied a computer in each room that worked on wireless technology , but its Microsoft Windows interface was Italian and we preferred to use our own computer and its programs .
When we arrived at home , we did some internet research on this and discovered that part of the issue might be the telephone 's specifications .
This page by HTC has some information on the model of HTC Desire we used : http://www.htc.com/www/smartphones/htc-desire-hd/#specs .
The page currently lists different networks for Europe and Asia Pacific -LRB- HSPA\/WCDMA : 900\/2100 MHz ; GSM : 850\/900\/1800 \/ 1900 MHz -RRB- but does not list info for North America .
My husband had discovered somewhere else online that different HTC models are sold in Europe and North America and this may make it work differently when crossing regions .

Would like to know if the carry on bag on the bus would be safe while we are off the bus , example if we keep meds in that case or should we keep in big suitcase which will be underneath , Thanks and looking forward to trip in 3 weeks
I tend to take enough for a day or two with me wherever I go in a small ` carry about ' and the rest goes in the main case or even in a regular carry-on under the bus .

I once asked a TD about the safety of doing that and the reply was that there was more likelihood of somebody stealing the entire bus than a case , albeit overnight when we and our cases are not in it .

If you think you may wish to do the same then bring a letter from your doctor detailing the meds you need just in case replacement is needed as many items can not be openly purchased in Europe as they are in the USA .
That is a tricky one as it rather depends on your ` meds ' and where you are going .
Any questions so far ... ?
Thank you , appreciate your help
As the Tour Director 's and the Driver 's personal things are also left on the bus you can rest assured that they keep it safe !
-LRB- During the day , that is - do n't leave anything on the bus overnight -RRB- .
Thank you , this is very reassuring
One more thing to keep in mind if your tour includes Venice .
The big Insight bus can not make it to the Hotel to unload luggage .
Instead they have to shuttle your luggage between the bus and the hotel .
Because of this , they will ONLY transport your one large piece of luggage .
Any hand luggage you bring on the trip either has to stay on the bus overnight or be carried with you all day .
I swapped out the things I was keeping in my hand luggage -LRB- my medication -RRB- for that part of the trip only .
Since I had read different opinions regarding the size of hand luggage before leaving on my trip , I was really curious what the truth was .
Most people brought small hand luggage or a backpack that fit under their seat .
There was plenty of room under the bus -LRB- a separate section just for hand luggage -RRB- for roller bags .
But our tour director confirmed that there would NOT be enough room if everyone brought overnight roller bags .
Very helpful , fortunately not Venice this time .

I have never attended Fan Fair , but I traveled through one time enroute to a funeral and could not find an open hotel room for 100 miles on either side of Nashville , so believe it when people say you have to book ahead .
I see the tickets for the concerts for June 7-10 , 2012 go on sale next week and the tour operators are taking deposits now for ticket\/accommodation packages .
The only transit I know of is the usual public bus system and a free shuttle among the venues , but not to area hotels .
Some hotels offer their own transportation .
Taxis are an option .
So whether you will need a car while in Nashville will depend on where you stay .
Factor any transport offered by a hotel into the alternative cost of renting a house .
There are some tour operators offering bus trips to Dollywood and\/or Memphis .
There is no rail and the long-distance bus option is not very good .
For example , Nashville to Memphis takes 4 hours with 3-4 buses per day at a cost of around $ 50 per person .
Then you would need a car or taxi to get to Graceland and other sights .
You could also fly between Nashville and Memphis , but you 'd need ground transport once in town .

Dollywood is in a small town not served directly by an airport or the bus as far as I know, so driving the 3.5 hours would get you there as opposed to flying into Knoxville and having to drive from there .
Hiring a vehicle large enough for 6 minivan ?
for the road trip east to Dollywood and\/or Southwest to Memphis is probably best if one of the tours does not match your interest .
Maybe there a place on the Fan Fare website where people with more experience discuss the details and give hints\/advice ?
On Saturday we picked up a brochure that was for an $ 11 pick up with Bay Shuttle from Nobb Hill in San Francisco to the airport .
We had a flight booked for 12pm but decided to allow hours which meant we wanted to depart at 9am .
I rang the company on Saturday and went ahead and booked our transfer to the airport for the Monday to come .
Monday morning came and so did 9am .
By 9.15 am we were a tad bit concerned .
I called the company and was told that no booking had been made under our name and no car was scheduled to come and pick us up .
Luckily we were in a good area and a taxi was available to take us to the airport .
Very disorganised and clearly wasnt paying much attention over the phone when the booking was made .
I pretty much use taxis now for home pickup but still use the airport shuttles that make regular rounds of the hotels .
I 've had that happen before with a door-to-door shuttle .
Its so frustrating isnt it ?
We are lucky we had left plenty of time but someone else may not be so lucky next time !
I live in San Francisco , and Bay Shuttle is my favorite company !
For a few years I make my reservations on-line as they always have Internet special .
Never had a no-show , always on time or a bit early .
Our son used them too , he never complained .
I wonder if you confirmed your reservation .
But this is just me , I always confirm everything
I 'm sorry for your frustration .
Probably a wrong timing .
We did the bay shuttle in San Francisco once but it did n't end up like this .
It went well for us .
We almost had this experience too .
You case is just a bit worse .
In our case , we were late and it was too crowded .

I 'm planning a trip to Bhutan and Nepal in the fall .
The trip is pretty expensive -LRB- compared to others I 've done -RRB- and I want insurance in case I have to cancel or change for any reason .
Who can advise me on a good company to use ?
This site does a comparison of various insurnace options
it 's been written up in quite a few publications which are linked on their website .
A lot of people recommend insuremytrip.com for comparisons .
Make sure your policy includes medical -LRB- if you do n't have cover abroad -RRB- and medical evacuation and repatriation .
There 's a discussion of medevac insurance on the Asia board right now .
I concur with insuremytrip.com .
It 's a great site to compare multiple policies !
Also , be forewarned that you will be a significant premium to obtain the `` cancel for any reason '' benefit and often you will only get 50-75 % of amount back .
Also , you need to purchase insurance quickly after paying for your trip in order to get the pre-existing conditions waiver .
If you study `` cancel for any reason '' policies , the amount you 're ultimately reimbursed , provided you are within all requirements and restrictions , is about equal to the premium .
Otherwise , cancellations and\/or changes are covered only for `` covered reasons '' and you must understand the terms and conditions , and , especially , the exclusions and requirements .
It 's critical to study the actual policy\/certificate and not rely on any overview or `` examples '' .
Weather , for example , is often excluded as a covered reason if your flight is canceled , unless the entire airport is closed for a certain number of hours .
One kind of insurance that I would have to recommend would be backing up any travel documents .
It 's something I 've been doing for the last couple of months and it 's proven quite effective so far .
All you do is go to accessmyid.com and they will take the load off your mind in case you come into any trouble re : passports or medical documents being lost , stolen or copied .
As for insuremytrip.com I 've had no problems with them in the past , but you have to study all `` cancel '' policies like djkbooks said .
That 's where these guys really make there money .
It 's a kind of insurance I like to have .
We used Cambell Irvine in the UK to insure our trip to Tanzania .
They were quite a bit cheaper -- offered more coverage with fewer exclusions than any US company I found .
Good price and coverage was what I needed .
I ended up purchasing through Travel Guard .
Hopefully I do n't need to use it !

I 'm really excited about this website i found !
You sign up for an account , and it organizes all the information you send it to it by tags .
For instance , you 're reading an article\/thread on Bologna .
You find a paragraph you want to take note of , so instead of cutting\/pasting it onto a word document , you click on your Diigo toolbar to get the highlighter pen .
You highlight the paragraph , then click bookmark with a `` bologna '' tag , and it goes straight to your bologna file on your diigo account !
It 's really easy to use , and a dream if you 're organizing a trip that includes different locations !

Are you familiar with this agency - not that it is a scam .
IF you do want to send a bank transfer all you do is go to your bank and ask them to do a bank transfer and give them the name and numbers the agency gave you .
The money comes out of your bank account .
Your money will go electronically to their bank as a deposit .
That is why you have to be sure of what you are doing .
Once your money is in their bank account they could close it out and you are out of luck .
Is this a USA agency or an Croatian agency ?
Bank transfers are a very common thing especially for apartment rentals and such .

It was at a fair .
It would be the only time I 'd wear a fanny pack .
Valuables are not safe on the beach .
If you drive to a beach , lock your valuables in the trunk -LRB- and make sure you close up passenger part as well , so trunk ca n't be accessed that way -RRB- .
Then take only your car key and beach needs -- water\/towels\/sunglasses \/ sunscreen etc. -- with you to the beach .

Leave your hotel room key at the front desk , use a disposable camera not a valuable one , do n't carry a charge card , etc. .

I understand it 's the northern summer in August -LRB- late -RRB- , but I 've heard San Francisco can get rather cool and misty .
Hi all - after tips on what types of clothing to bring .
Will be staying at a lodge near Mariposa outside Yosemite .
I intend bringing shorts , t-shirts and 3\/4 pants but will I need any warm jackets ?
Appreciate all advice ~ thanks !
Yes , San Francisco can be quite cool .
And Yosemite is in the mountains so it could be cool .
I would definitely take a pair of long pants and a light jacket and perhaps a warm sweater or fleece .
I do n't live in that area but have visited there several times .
Yes you 'll will likely need a jacket at some point .
I would bring ` layering ' options like a long sleeve tshirt , fleece vest , windbreaker type jacket , in addition to the shorts and capris .
It 's a local joke in SF about tourists in shorts
They do n't sell all those fleece jackets with `` San Francisco '' written on them down at Fisherman 's Wharf for nothin ' !
Yosemite will likely be very warm\/hot during the day and quite cool\/cold in the evenings .
Mariposa would likely be even warmer than in Yosemite Valley , and not so cool at night .

If there is a heat wave in the central part of the State , then SF will be either very cold and foggy -- or -- have its own heat wave -LRB- which is the worse option since the city is not built for heat -RRB- .
It all depends on the weather patterns at the time of your visit .
Post here maybe 5-7 days before your trip and we can give you an idea what to expect .
Now - there is no telling .
Thanks all - very handy tips .

Keep it on air-plane mode until you get to a wifi zone .
Gazillions of these in London and I assume Paris is the same .
I downloaded a city guide ap that listed them out for me when I went to Amsterdam .
I regularly skype iphone to iphone from UK to Germany on wifi .
Its free and the quality is brilliant .
Do n't known your home country but assume it is Europe ?
It depends on the country , but still expensive .
Use Skype , although the call quality varies .
Unless you have set up your phone to push email and texts , then you are really in control of your usage .
My suggestion would be to use text messaging more than voice since it 's cheaper .
And if you really feel you need to call home to check up , then call AT
Turn this off immediately upon your return .
Where you really run up costs is in data roaming , and that 's very expensive .
Do n't put your phone in Airplane mode because that turns off all the cell features -LRB- and prevents you from getting calls -RRB- .
But keep data roaming turned off and only access the internet from a Wi-Fi hotspot -LRB- preferably a free one -RRB- .
You do n't hear nearly as many horror stories from international use as you did at one time because data roaming is turned off now initially , as is the push-email function .
Keep them that way and you should have no problems .
And tell everyone to call you only in a true emergency .

North America runs on 110 volts .
When traveling in Europe I was told to use an extra piece of equipment between the adapter and my electronics so they do n't get `` fried '' by the change in voltage .
Or at least I think that 's how it works .
It is somewhat heavy and I would rather not take it if I do n't need to .
Does anyone know more about this ?
the newer models of hair dryers , etc , have two settings , 120 and 240 v.
In Europe you can do without the transformer -LRB- that 's the extra equipment -RRB- if you can switch to 240 v -LRB- volts . -RRB-
Otherwise , you need the transformer between the NA plug and the european plug .
It depends on whether or not you have `` newer '' equipment .
Ahhhh , it 's a transformer .
I was more concerned for my camcorder , phone etc. .
Look carefully on the sides to see if you see a switch that says 120v\/240v .
Or look in the manual if you still have it , or look the model up on the web .
Pretty well all modern electronics are dual voltage so that they can handle the two different systems .
Just look at the little tag that has all the electricity information and you 'll see `` INPUT ''
Next to that you 'll likely see something like he mentioned above - 100-240v
On electronics like my netbook or PSP , it was on the little brick in the cord .
On my battery chargers for my cameras , it 's on the charger .
If you see that 100-240v under the INPUT , you wo n't get fried .
All you need is the cheap , very light weight adapter for the actual plug so that you can , essentially , put a square plug into a round socket -LRB- or vice versa -RRB- .
Exactly as Gordon has said .
Not hard to find .
of course , you have to remember to switch to 240 v when you get to Europe !

We may -LRB- still kind of up in the air -RRB- be going to Canada by train in July .
My father and I have passports , but my son does not .
He 's about to turn 15 .

I 'm thinking to save a little money and just get him a travelcard , since I 'm thinking it 's much more likely that he 'll be going to Canada and\/or on a cruise than somewhere that requires an actual passport and we 're not completely sure he 's going anywhere !

The only thing that is giving me hesitation is the inability to fly into Mexico or the Caribbean with it , although I ca n't imagine why he 'd need too -LRB- Spring break trips would occur only over my dead body , and he 's mildly disabled and is still very childlike , so it 's very hard to imagine him traveling by himself , although he should be able to eventually -RRB- .
Are there any other pitfalls I 'm not aware of ?
Also , does anyone know why you have the option to get a book AND a card at the same time ?
Why would you need the card if you have the book ?
You get both a passport and a travel card together so you have a back-up document in case you lose the passport .
If you travel frequently overseas it 's a lot easier to have a lost or stolen passport replaced if you have a legally valid document to prove both identity an d citizenship .
But in your sons case , if you do n't plan on allowing your son to travel independently , then there 's no need to get both .
But a passport is always better than a travel card , though it 's your choice .
I 'd just say that you are cutting things awfully close , however .
Your probably going to pay expediting fees to get either document by July .
That does make sense .
We were figuring that having the travel card would make it easier to get him a passport if he needed one down the road .
I 'm hoping we 'll get away with not expediting , but we 'll see what the passport people say .
This really just came up as an option , since my dad just decided that he wanted to see Montreal again and , since he is no longer comfortable traveling independently , take at least me with him .
We 'd both prefer if my son could go as well , since he loves to travel , and enjoys the kind of history-focused trips my dad plans .

We 're considering buying new luggage and wondering about the durability of hard-shell luggage .
Does it crack or break easily -LRB- for instance if dropped when being loaded into airplane , or if heavy bags are dumped on top -RRB- ?
What are people 's recommendations about it vs. soft luggage ?
They have lasted ten years so far and are still good .
We also have soft sided cases we bought last year - one is wrecked after just two flights .
Softsides are more flexible - you can always squeeze one more thing in , but hard cases are my choice for our next cases .

The only reason to get new ones is the towing comfort - the old ones have two wheels close together , and so have a tendency to tip over , whereas modern ones have them on the short side which is better for towing .
We have a couple of hardshell cases .
We always check our luggage .
I can push easily with one hand without all that pulling especially when it 's heavy .
I bought Hey 's from Costco 's , for 99.00 I got a 25 '' and 21 '' .
I agree you can squeeze an extra item in but the hard shell protects better .
They are also ultra light weight -LRB- 6_ニ___ニ__1\/2 lbs -RRB- to fit in with the weight restrictions of most airlines .
My sister has had Samsonite hard shells for 5 yrs , travels a lot , loves them and has had no problems with breakage .
Just used my first hard shell 25 '' with spinner wheels .
What a difference with spinner wheels .
While hard shell luggage is extremely durable , it 's also quite heavy .
Hard shell luggage can also be unwieldy at times .
However , the luggage is very sturdy and keeps your stuff safe from damage .
Since soft-shell suitcases are easily maneuverable , you can squeeze them into an aircraft 's overhead bin or the boot of your car .
Also , soft-shell luggage can have the expandability feature and loads of interior and exterior compartments , which may not be possible with hard shell luggage .
Keeping all of this in mind , I would definitely recommend a soft-shell suitcase made from a strong material like ballistic nylon .
Some of the known brands that make good quality soft-sided luggage include Tumi -LRB- http://intl.tumi.com/ -RRB- , Victorinox Swiss Army -LRB- http://www.victorinox.com/ -RRB- , and Briggs
Both have their pros and cons .

I will have a week to a few days notice .
I 'd have a couple places in mind , then keep track of plane fares online .
I can often get economical flights to Hawaii or Mexico without much notice -LRB- from Seattle , for example -RRB- .
Same principal with hotels , I 'd have a short-list of places that sound nice in your budget , and call them direct once you book the flights .
With the internet , even a last minute trip , does n't have to mean going to the airport without a ticket , or landing in a city without a place to stay .
You can sign up with airlines for weekend specials , as well as with outfits like smartertravel , travelzoo , farefinder etc for weekly emails of near-in specials .
I believe you can register at sites like expedia and travelocity to be notified when a particular route goes down in price .

Basically , sign up with any site that offers cheap rates close in .

It seems that everyone I mention to that I am going to Italy has advice for me .

Is this true ?
I spent a month in Italy last September with my husband and did not need a skirt at all to visit churches .
I wore capris below the knee , tops with sleeves and never needed to cover my head .
My husband did not wear shorts on the days we visited churches but was able to enter in `` cut off '' pants .
Your friends may be confusing Italy with Greece where ladies must wear a skirt to enter the monasteries of Meteora .
Hi Judy : We have been to Italy twice and never needed a skirt or dress .

I have always worn slacks or capris and definitely a top with sleeves -- The scarf would be needed if your top was sleevless or if you wanted to dress up an outfit -- no need to wear something on your head -LRB- I think I did that when we went into mosques -RRB- .

Looking back on some of our photos , my husband did not wear shorts in any of the countries we visited when we were going to visit churches\/temples\/mosques of any denomination-Everyone is different -- that is us -- wear what you feel is right for you and enjoy your trip .
We did wear jackets at times mostly in the evening and it was September-also 5 years ago and the weather -LRB- global warming -RRB- has changed quite a bit since then .

Flying in from Europe back to JFK at 9:00 at night .
No flights back to MIami , Florida that late .
Should I stay over at hotel near JFK , and fly out of JFK the next morning , back to Miami , or taxi to a hotel near Laguardia , and fly out of Laguardia in the morning ?
My New York friends tell me it 's easier to deal with Laguardia .
If you can fly out of JFK , why would you bother with trekking over to LGA ?
JFK is n't that bad , and you 'll have to deal with immigration and customs there anyway .
Not to mention the added cost of a taxi .
If you 're already arriving at JFK , I do n't think it makes any sense to go to Laguardia .
But again if you 're already at JFK , yes I would simply overnight at\/near the airport and continue on to Miami in the morning .
Perhaps your NY friends mean generally-speaking that Laguardia is a smaller easier airport to deal with ?
What your friends likely mean is that LGA is closer to Midtown and easier to reach from most of New York .
Once already at JFK , there is little reason to make the cross-island trek to fly out of LGA .
In that case go there if it 's easier to get to their place .
Are you staying with friends who live close to LGA ?
Here are some potential pitfalls of -LRB- family -RRB- travel - based on our experiences - and how best to deal with them .

While I disagreed with the general tenor of this post : http://www.fodors.com/community/travel-tips-trip-ideas/posting-links-to-blogs.cfm - I am getting rather tired of seeing posts from you that are just links .
It 's becoming clear that you 're simply trying to drive traffic to your site .
If you have something interesting to say , say it here .
If you just want to post links , use Twitter .
I would rather respond directly to you than here , but I ca n't find any way of doing it .
I 'm truly sorry you are offended by my postings .
Yes , I do link to my blog .
I used to just blog in a variety of places , like Travelblog ; however the time and tedium of posting photos caused me to try consolidate it all into one place only .
I can not believe I 'm the only person who has found this to be so .

Of course I could just cut and paste reports , but personally when I 'm reading about a place I 'm interested in , I 'm generally attracted to the photos more than anything else , as it tends to pique my curiosity about the place .
Before we travel anywhere , I spend a lot of time reading trip reports , not only to get excited about the destination , but for tips and advice .
I would hope the same is true of my postings .
Although I now see the ` linking ' system is controversial , I did n't realize this until the discussion started a few days ago .

I enjoy blogging and writing about our family 's travels and being part of a travel community ; I know from feedback that some people - only a few to be sure - like reading about our travels , as I do about other family 's .

When we tried to provide Hotwire with our payment information , the list of countries that Hotwire recognizes does not include any post-Communist countries .
They like Columbia , the Philippines , and even Trinidad and Tobago , but if you live in Poland , Slovenia , or the Slovak Republic -- take your business elsewhere .
-LRB- By the way , Hotwire likes Uruguay , but not Paraguay . -RRB-
Hotwire 's website refused to create an account for us , and their Customer Service wrote :
`` We accept international credit cards from most countries , but only from those that are listed on our billing page .
If Czech Republic is not listed , then we are not able to accept that credit card . ''
-LRB- `` most countries '' -- Hotwire lies so beautifully -RRB-
`` Before booking , I recommend you refer to the information on our site regarding payment options .
You do not need an account to book a hotel reservation with Hotwire ; as their website states : `` You can continue without signing in and create an account later . ''
Moreover , you can pay with PayPal -LRB- thereby dodging Hotwire 's reluctance to accept credit cards from a random selection of countries -RRB- .
When you hit the account creation screen , though , you 're dead in the water if you reside in any of Hotwire 's pariah countries .
Repeat : You can make your payment with PayPal .
Then , you can not create an account on Hotwire .
That 's either scary or criminal -- I 'm not sure which .
Needless to say , we took our business to a different web company , where we quickly booked a hotel with zero hassles .
I really wonder which psychosis moves the management at Hotwire .
This can be found on our site at :
-LRB- The link is broken . -RRB-
The next day , we received an email message from Hotwire with the subject : `` Welcome to Hotwire !
Your registration was successful '' .
The body of the message was completely empty .
Hotwire 's Magnum Opus
Interesting 1st -LRB- and only -RRB- post .

My husband and I are traveling to Spain in a couple of weeks .
We are bringing our digital cameras , but we are not sure if using an outlet adapter is safe for the batteries .
Is it safe to use an outlet adapter to charge the camera batteries ?
When I was in Italy I used an adapter with a US hairdryer and the dryer never worked again .
I 've charged camera batteries using an adaptor many times without any problems .
If not , then you would have also had to use a converter .
Most electronic chargers , cord nowadays do n't need a converter -LRB- e.g. cell phone , camera , laptop -RRB- , but you can double check by looking the what input voltage it accepts .
If it says something like 100V-240V ~ no converter is needed .
As a tip , I always bring an extension cord with me .
Often outlets are not in convenient places .
I plug my chargers , blowers , etc. into the cord and the cord into the adaptor giving me greater flexibility .
When you used your hair dryer with an adaptor , did you remember to switch the voltage ?
If your battery charger has 100-220V listed on it , all you need is the plug adaptor .
is\/are the plug adaptor -LRB- s -RRB-
for Europe -LRB- not UK -RRB- and Israel the same ?
I 'd check on line or at a travel store to see what adaptors are needed .
You would n't want to be sorry once you get there ... .
If you are charging AA batteries , I bought a dual voltage travel charger at Radio Shack on clearance for $ 2 .
It only holds two batteries at a time .
I charge two at night while I have two others in my camera .
You can buy chargers at Walmart , Radio Shack , etc. , just make sure they are dual voltage .

We will be staying in Florance , Italy for a week and our next stay will be in Barga , what is the best way to get there and how long will it take ?
Rodney , you can find out by going to trenitalia.com for the Italian trains and look for Florence .
Also , you could post this on the Europe board .
You 'll have better luck if you title it something like : How to get to Barga from Florence .
If I could underline Florence , I would .
You can take the train from Florence to either Fornaci di Barga or the next stop , Gallicano-Barga .
Barga itself is still 4-5 km away .
You would have to change trains in Lucca and the trip takes about three hours .
If possible , I suggest you rent a car and drive there , since you will probably need a car while visiting the area .
According to Googlemaps , the drive from Florence is 108 km and takes 1 hour 46 minutes .

We 're leaving in a month for our super long trip that we really have no idea how long it will be .
What was your process , and where did you leave it all ?
What was the most random and un-explainable item you decided to keep ?
Well , sort of .
My longest trip so far was ten months .
My packing list and `` leaving home '' list are on my blog - mytimetotravel.wordpress.com .
However , it sounds like you are n't keeping your house , if I had been doing that I would probably have put some stuff in storage .
I gave away all my electrical items to family and friends -LRB- not enough time to sell them -RRB- .

The first time I was single and had very little -LRB- a kettle , a lamp , hairdrier -RRB- but the second time as a family of 4 we gave away tons of stuff with the understanding we would reclaim it if we returned within 2 years but 8 years later we have not .
When single I owned very little furniture but I did manage to sell the few items to a friend that had just purchased a house .
We took most of our furniture with us the second time as we were moving overseas and the company paid for a container .
Both times we pared back clothing , books , well everything really .
except odd earrings I thought I could n't part with that I subsequently threw out .
So , my advice is take what you absolutely need and love and leave anything else with generous family or friends .
I 've done this twice and both times I was relatively unprepared !
it 's surprising how freeing such a move can be and I do n't regret getting rid of anything .
I 'd have to look in the basement for the most random thing I decided to keep ... nothing comes to mind .
My sister still has some of my stuff in her garage .
Well , at least I think she does but she has moved in the meantime and to be honest I 'm not entirely sure if she 's kept it or for that matter I 'm not sure exactly what I left with her !
Are you emptying your living space ?
Getting rid of your house or apartment ?
You have to pack everything up and put it into storage ?

When I really need to pare back -LRB- we lived in a camper for a couple of years -RRB- -- I think in terms of `` what do I need for a week '' -- within reason , of course .

What is the best place to stowe a laptop while you are out sightseeing or on business ?
Do you leave it in the room ?
Lock it in the trunk ?
Leave it at the hotel desk ?
Take it with you ?
Each of these options carry some risk of theft .
I do not stay in high-end hotels , but I do try to stay in safe neighborhoods .
What works best , and what should I avoid .
Most of my travels are in Western Europe , where crime rates are relatively low , but everyone who travels with a laptop faces this question .
I am asking because I am taking a laptop with me for the first time .
I took a netbook to France last spring , and locked it in my backpack when I did n't take it with me .
Mostly I did n't take it with me .
If it 's an ordinary-sized laptop , I 'd opt for the trunk .
However , I try to transfer it when no one is looking .
If there 's an in-room safe , and it fits , that 's the way to go .
We leave it in the hotel room , on full display .
It 's insured in the hotel , not in the car .

There is an easy way to see just how long your freezer has been without power .
Take a glass and pour about a 1/2 inch of water in it .
Place it in the freezer .
After the water is frozen , place a coin on top of the frozen water .
Then just leave it in the freezer .
When you come home and you know the power has been off , take a look at the coin .
It is still on top ?
Or is it at the bottom ?
By the way , I think the idea behind having only a 1/2 inch of water is that you want to give the ice the chance to melt , should the opportunity present itself .
You come home from your trip .
The handful of clocks are blinking , letting you know that the power has been off .
But for how long ?
You ca n't tell !
What about the food in the freezer ?
Is it still good ?
Sure , it 's frozen now , but maybe it 's been thawed for the past few days .
That 's a good idea CubFan .
It 's something I 've never thought about but I 'd hate to have to make a decision to throw away a lot of food that may be good .
I beleive , ` when in doubt , throw it out '' Going to freeze that half inch of water now , and hope that I do n't forget why it 's there .
I do a similar thing ... but I just put a couple of the big square ice cubes on a flat plate .
If it still looks like an ice cube I am safe , if it is flat on the plate I am not !
Although I suppose you could also just ask your neighbors .
Just make sure your freezer is properly shut too before leaving on a trip .
We returned home to find once that was not the case and lost a freezer full of steaks , roasts , venison , lamb etc. .
what a horrible stink plus about $ 300.00 plus of lost meat .
Thanks for your household tip , Cub , that is an excellant idea as is yours jules .
We are in the process of eating our way through our freezer
We try to do that before going away since we had friends that had a similar situation to you LoveItaly .
For the first time in years , we had to use our insurance .
We had to cancel for medical\/surgical reasons this month and the cost of the trip for both was over $ 15,000 .
The insurance company only wants to pay us $ 7800 .
We booked through Grand Circle , paid in full and are wondering now why we bothered !
All the past premiums and now they have fuzzy math and do n't want to reimburse .
We really love this company -LRB- GRAND CIRCLE -RRB- and have referred lots of people but if this is the way insurance works , why bother !
Anyone else had problems with Grand Circle\/OATS with TRIP MATE ?
Maybe I 'm the first to experience this and I would never want to spread bad rumors and if I did n't read the small print ; shame on me !
At this point , I expected more from Grand Circle !
PLEASE RESPOND DIRECT TO MY EMAIL ;
I ca n't offer any specific advice but a quick google search for OATS Trip Mate seems to turn up a number of complaints .
Some are report on the website of someone named Christopher Elliott , who seems to intervene from time to time on complaints like yours .

But he usually points out that there can be a difference between the fine print of your insurance policy and what you might have been told over the phone - only the former is binding , so you might want to check -LRB- or recheck your written policy -RRB- to see if your situation truly comes within its terms .
First , read everything .
I had to make a claim once with Access America and was given incorrect information over the phone initially .
I was told that flight cancellation due to weather was excluded , when in fact in was not .
Also , carefully follow the directions and requirements for claims submission and make sure you have the correct documentation .
Note that with medical claims , you must make sure your doctor gets the reason right the first time as it can not be modified later .
What do you mean by `` fuzzy math '' ?
Usually , you are covered in full , up to a certain amount -LRB- generally at least as much as you paid -RRB- .
Sometimes with cruise coverage you can rebook , but if you want a refund - it 's only partial .
Have you checked with Grand Circle ?
Travel insurance covers non-refundable prepaid costs , so if some was refundable , you 'd have to collect that from Grand Circle ?
It 's hard to know if the insurance company is being reasonable or not without any details .
What you can get up on cancellation is often limited by when you buy the insurance and by what the specific circumstances are regarding the cancellation .

We 're looking forward to hearing about your experience with the planner .
If you have any comments or questions , just click on the feedback form in the top left-hand corner of the planner 's screen .

What country is best for an American to learn Arabic in an immersion setting ?
Of course , things like safety and political stability are important .
I was thinking Turkey ...

They speak Turkish in Turkey , not Arabic , so you 're not going to find the immersion setting you 're looking for -LRB- or at least not any more than you 'd find taking Arabic in New York City -RRB- .
With one or two exceptions , I do n't think you should let concerns about security\/political stability influence your choice of an Arabic immersion course in a country to speaks Arabic .

Frankly , in countries like Morocco , Egypt and Jordan -LRB- some of the countries that have Arabic programs and that are also reputed to present security concerns -RRB- , you face a significantly greater risk every day in your hometown of being in a car accident or being hit by a car as a pedestrian .
The exceptions -LRB- countries that have Arabic language programs but that do present , in my view , some risks in terms of security and political stability -RRB- are Syria and Lebanon .
Probably the safest place you could go that has a well-established program is Al Ain , in the United Arab Emirates .
Have a look at the information at www.amerispan.com/language-schools/United-Arab-Emirates/Al-Ain/3610 Al Ain is a moderately sized city , about 100 miles from Dubai , on the border with Oman .
The program offerings are relatively limited , but they do have a summer school option .
Oman would be another great choice .
My husband and I visited there last spring and we felt it is the safest place we 've ever been to in our entire lives -LRB- including the small towns I grew up in in Canada -RRB- .

It felt so safe , we picked up hitchhikers -LRB- and they were very nice young men , too , exceptionally polite and friendly -RRB- ... However , I have n't been able to find any information on immersion programs in Oman .
I know this is an old thread , but Egypt has the most options -LRB- e.g. , AUC programs -RRB- .
Important to consider , though , whether you want to learn the standard written language -LRB- fusha -RRB- or if you want to learn to speak a dialect .
There are also programs in Jordan , Lebanon and Palestine that are excellent if the interest is in fusha with Levantine dialect .
I 'm not sure I would ever take an Arabic course in Morocco as the dialect and vocabulary are different .
I would go with Egypt as well .

It is approximately in the middle of the Arabic speaking countries and is also the center of the Arab film industry so if you learn Egyptian Arabic , you will -LRB- probably -RRB- be understood in other Arab countries .
Personally I would definitely learn street Arabic - unless you 're a scholar who wants to be fluent and read and write texts .

The island is about 120 kilometers long and between 5 and 25 kilometers wide .
Dozens of lakes , rainforest and huge sandblows cover vast parts of the island .
People who visit Fraser Island for the first time often struggle to find the words to describe the beauty of this magical island .
But also animal life , especially the 230 species of birds , Australia 's purest dingo 's and many other species contribute to the unique island environment . ''
You could spend some time there and then head back to Noosa or Mooloolaba for a great beach holiday .

Another question from dap1206 .
Which credit card works best in the Mediterranian for ATMs and if possible fee free .
When we traveled to Australia we used Capital One and Bank of America because they were aligned with PAC West bank .
You want to use a debit card in an ATM machine , not a credit card .
The credit card considers it a `` cash advance '' and has a horrific interest rate attached .
Never EVER use a credit card in an ATM unless it is an emergency .
The `` best '' card is always relative .
I still prefer Capital One because it does n't add on an extra foreign exchange fee .
If BOA is aligned with banks in your destination , then it 's also doable , but you 'll still pay the 3 % foreign exchange fee whether you have a withdrawal fee or not .
Unlike as in the U.S. , typically , banks in Europe do not charge their own withdrawal fee for foreign bank cards .
So you only have to worry about the fees and foreign exchange charges of your own credit card or ATM .
But I agree with everyone else : Unless there 's absolutely no alternative , never ever withdraw cash as an advance on your credit card .
The rates are horrible .
I always refer to the following page before I travel for info on which cards are best -LRB- both debit and credit . -RRB-
Since it is a wiki , it seems to be updated regularly .
With more and more states cracking down on using the cell phone while driving , I have decided that I need to get a car with with a hands free option .
I am torn between getting a car with a built-in bluetooth speaker phone or getting OnStar and a voice plan .
What are you experiencers with built-in hands free speaker phones ?
What are you experiences with using OnStar as a phone ?
Hands-free only allowed in the Netherlands - otherwise a hefty fine -LRB- 140 - 600 in Portugal ! -RRB-
My husband has a Prius which has Bluetooth built in .
It works brilliantly , and can be programmed for several phones , so i can use it with my phone when I borrow his car .
I have a Bluetooth headset I use in my car , which also works very well , especially with my phone allowing voice activated dialling .
Although it may be legal to use hands-free phones in places where you ca n't use hands-on , please be aware that using hands-free cell phones is almost or just as bad .
The issue is not so much that your hands are in use for something other than driving , but that your brain is .
Conversations with people in the vehicle are different than ones with those on the phone .
Others in the vehicle are aware of the driving conditions and will naturally stop conversation as needed so that the driver can give full attention to the road .
Please consider never driving and talking on the phone regardless of hands-free .
If you need to make a call , pull over .
If someone calls you , let it go to voice-mail and check it when you 've stopped .
-LRB- stepping down off my soap box ... -RRB-

As far as FF programs , it depends on your home airport and who the carriers are with the most flights .
Many airline FF programs are part of an alliance , so that you can use your miles on partner airlines .

My home airline -LRB- meaning they have the most non-stop flights out of my airport -RRB- , USAir , is part of the Star Alliance , so I can earn and use miles on their partners , including United , Lufthansa and SwissAir among others .
Delta is a part of the Skyteam Alliance which has a whole other set of partners .
And American is part of the One World Alliance with yet another set of partners .
As for hotel programs , I belong to most of them , but tend towards the Hilton brands and the Starwood brands .
I sort of like the Starwood program a bit more , because they allow you to use points plus a little cash for redemption stays .
But for business travel , I prefer the Hilton brands .
All of the programs I 've mentioned have international partners or presence so would work for your European vacations .

Many of our guests elect to only take a purse , pocketbook or small camera bag onto the coach , while stowing the `` main '' carry-on underneath .

Most of the times , since we never allow more than 40 guests on our coaches , there is plenty of space for your carry-on in the compartment of luggage hold next to the front door ; your tour director will assist you in stowing your bag as you board , and you retrieve it when you exit the coach .
This makes entry and egress easy and comfortable , and you do n't have to worry about space issues .

Pickpockets are often a topic on the BB .

Thanks for posting that , we must all keep our valuables well hidden and I would never keep anything more than my water bottle and make up in a back back .
As stated on this forum before , I had an attempt on my ` Packsafe '' handbag in Paris last year .
It held up , a bit worse for wear , but I never felt the attempt at all , my cash of course was hidden else where .

You must be careful about your things and money while on travel .
Thanks for sharing very important information here with us .
We were reading tips about pickpockets it is suggested not to take jewellery what are thoughts about diamond engagement ring ?
Hi Laff , well I always take mine and a few others , I keep my gold necklace at home though .
It can be confronting and both you and I will be bombarded with the hard sell from the cafe in Belgium to the bag sellers in Italy .
My neighbor left her rings at home only to have a break in at her Brisbane home .
Rings are ok in my opinion , flashy gold necklace that could pulled off from a motorbike I think not a good idea .

I try to NEVER give them any reason for picking on me , no wallets in eye view , no cords around my neck that obviously have a wallet on the end , its really important to keep your wits about you , but tens of thousands of tourists every day have no trouble .

I always stick to a few simple rules , no obvious wallets , I usually never have more than 50 euro in my handbag , carry any camera or bag across the body , use the hotel safe -LRB- having given it a dry run to make sure it works -RRB- on public transport to talk in a low voice and look as though I know where to go and I try to pull into a building to read a map .
I always try to learn a few words in the language , I speak a bit of french and it was handy to say `` no thanks '' in a cheerful tone if ever approached by the countless bag sellers and the like .
I know many tourists only where costume jewellery in europe , but I think the camera or wallet in the hip pocket will get much more attention !
Look on all my trips I have seen these gypsies and the like everywhere , in Paris its like swatting flies to keep then at bay , but most are just looking for the easy target .
I guess its not what we are used to .
Not long to we leave for us 2 weeks tomorrow !
Indeed Laff , less for us , ca n't wait , got so much in London planed , then booking some tours in Paris and thinking about going to the Paris Opera !
This video wil be very useful to avoid them .
The technique was amazing of pickpocketers .
Thanks for sharing this here with us .

Anyone traveling to London via Heathrow before Sept 5 may want to consider using the Heathrow Connect or Heathrow Express .
The Heathrow connect is offering 50 % off one way or return tickets used before Sept 5 -LRB- promotion code HEC50 -RRB- .
Heathrow Express has a deal for two or more for a roundtrip -LRB- return -RRB- ticket only .
Both have to be purchased in advance on the internet .
Links for the discounts can be found on their home pages .
Both services run between Heathrow and Paddington Train station , which is near Hyde Park .
A short taxi ride to anywhere in London , especially the Marble Arch Area .
I believe the Heathrow Connect was just a little over 7 pounds for two people one way .

There are a lot of variables depending on the tour , how far apart the cities are , and so on , but as a general rule , the coach will stop about every hour and a half to two hours .
There tends to be a mid-morning `` coffee '' stop , a noon stop , a mid-afternoon stop , and then you reach your destination .

Welcome to the bulletin board and congratulations on your upcoming tour .
You say you are going on your first tour but not the destination .
On July 1st we begin our tour `` European Spotlight '' accordingly , we visit major cities of London , Amsterdam , and Paris .
Do we need dress-up clothes -LRB- eg .
suit jacket for men , dresses for the ladies ?
In a word no , we usually do the smart casual thing .

HOWEVER , that being said , read Rick Steve 's guide on how not to stand out either , my husband wears smart black jeans and a smart casual shirt with dark walking shoes like `` Rockport '' He has a lightweight slack for Italy , Spain etc and takes a smart leather jacket -LRB- not his best one -RRB-
I usually wear a skirt or dress most days as I find that more comfortable for long days on the coach .

I also have what I call `` Church clothes '' If I know that I will be going to visit a church , which I guess is the whole of France and Italy , I dress with the due respect I would expect to see in my own church and indeed many times have seen people made to cover up before they go in , one woman on my last tour was just refused entry at St Peters and not even given the chance to cover up !

Most people just change into a nicer top for the dinners , you are so on the go the you really do n't have time to dress up and I could n't count the times I have come home with most of my case unused .
Enjoy your tour , the packing thing is difficult , the golden rule is not to take clothes just in case !
I wear just slip on shoes with a padded sole and take warm boots as well .
I know whatever we wear we stand out like tourists but I do try to blend in as much as I can .

For my next trip in August , which is for 4 weeks , I intend to take under 10kg with we , one dress -LRB- my church one , its longer -RRB- one pair of jeans , two skirts , 6 tops and my leather jacket and some layered tops that go over everything .

I am wondering whether ladies -LRB- or men -RRB- are allowed to carry a hand bag as well as a cabin bag on the plane .
I have looked on the Qantas web site and British Airways site but ca n't seem to find the answer .
Does anyone know .
We have been on several flights overseas with Qantas and BA and never had any trouble .
In fact I usually have a cabin bag , a handbag or camera bag and a walking stick .
I have heard from other people that BA are getting more strict and will only allow one bag .
The last time we flew BA I had two bags , but I believe things are changing , especially as there seems to be less room now that the wheeled bags are being used .
I think this rule depends on the security situation at the time .
For a while , we were only allowed to take one bag through security at Heathrow .
I had to be able to stuff my purse into my carry-on .
Then Heathrow relaxed the rule .
After the most recent security alarm in the U.S. they were using that one-bag rule for a while and that one bag could not include anything with wheels .
Now , I believe you can only have one carry-on plus a computer , camera or purse etc. .
So , I think the answer is that you have to check to see what the situation is at the time you travel .
-LRB- Now that 's a challenge ! -RRB-
The following link will take you to the BA site but checking closer to the time is best .
Hi I have noticed on my upcoming tour that I have some free time to explore in Bratislava -LRB- maybe 2 hours -RRB- does anyone have any suggestions of what I could do in this short time .

It is a historic City and it contains a number of medieval castles \/ fortifications plus there is the river of course .
A delightful location in my opinion .
You could head for Bratislava Castle which is the seat of the Hungarian Kings and Queens of old .
It has a wonderful museum .
Or maybe just a walk in the castle grounds and by the riverside etc. ...
If neither of these options are pleasing to you then you may have booked the wrong trip .
Our local guide , Martin , had written a pictorial guide souvenir book which many of us purchased .
It is a lovely souvenir and I think it would be helpful for anyone walking about on their own .
If that 's not available , there are lots of resources on the Web including http://visit.bratislava.sk/en/
I remember walking around the old town area , having my lunch which as a wiener on a bun purchased at a take-out window and sitting in the square to eat it .
The local market was fun to walk through as well .
The 2 hours zipped by !

The airline allows me to check a bag and have a carry on .
Am I allowed to have a carry on on the coach and if so what size or type -LRB- eg duffel bag or small case with wheels -RRB- am I allowed to take with me ?
The storage space above your coach seat is much less than on an aeroplane .
Insight used to provide a free carry on bag which measured 11 `` H x 15 `` W x 7 `` D approximately and was soft and that size fitted in the overhead tray on the coach .
Some people bring normal roll-on carry-on 's and load them in the storage area under the bus each day but they will be largely inaccessible during the day .

My wife and I have always each used a small backpack which contains water , camera gear , tissues , travel books , stationery , pharmaceuticals , lightweight waterproof jacket and sometimes a foldup umbrella .
We place these on the floor of the coach under the seat in front and my wife uses them as an additional footrest .
Travelling in cold regions like Switzerland , we will place a coat or sweater on the overhead rack .

As long as it does n't have wheels .

We are flying with Emirates from Australia to Europe with a 5 hr stop over for re-fueling in Dubi .
Can anyone offer any insight into Dubi airport and suggestions for what to do in this time ?
Dubai airport is massive , and there are a lot of shops there - mostly normal airport-type shopping , but there are also some shops where you can get some quality souvenirs of Dubai .
You may take a while to get through the formalities , so the time you have there probably wo n't be enough to leave the airport to see anything .
There are plenty of places to eat , and coffee shops - but expensive .
There is also free wireless internet available in the lounges if that 's any good to you .
The airport does have alot of lounges that you can sleep on but these were always taken .
lots of people were alseep on the floor as well .
You can only look and shop for so long so unfortunately you will have time on your hands .
We had a stopover for the same duration and it really did drag due to the long haul from Australia to Dubai .

I booked well ahead of our holiday and was given this flight by my TA thinking this was the only available flight but it turned out that there were others who had a connecting flight within an hour of the Australia-Dubai leg , so i was pretty annoyed we did n't get that flight .
Dubai airport has so much to see and do .
BUT if do you buy something to take home do not buy the fur covered camels .
Quarantine will take them off you and destroy them .
The painted camels and donkeys are fine , but anything with sticks or stuffed saddle bags you lose .
We were lucky we only lost the sticks and bags off ours but some of the camels are very well glued and if Quarantine ca n't dismantle it safely you lose it .

Just thought I would mention it because when we got to Quarantine and said we had wooden items and stopped over in Dubai the Quarantine officer groaned and said `` tell me you did n't buy a camel '' Oops .
Just a heads up .

We had heaps to declare - food -LRB- candy -RRB- wooden objects , a horn cup and a whole heap of stuff on the declare it or lose it list and we only lost the sticks and bags off our camel and a wooden christmas decoration .
it 's hard to choose
The lady was really nice about it too .

Has anyone recently had to transit through Heathrow Airport Terminal 3 to Terminal 5 .
I would like to know how long it took as I have only be given 90 minutes between flights and I have been told that I need at least 3 hours due to all the security checks .
I have done this on a few occasions , but generally with two to three hours to play with .
When you travel in transit the security checks are fairly painless and quick .
Usually once you arrive at the first terminal you follow all the signs directing in-transit passengers .

-LRB- generally your luggage should be checked through so you do n't have to collect it and re-check it in -RRB- You hop on the bus to the terminal you need to go to , usually around a 15 to 20 minute ride .
Once you arrive at your terminal you place your hand luggage on the conveyer to be screened , walk through the security check - show your passport and go right through to the departure area .
You can either go directly to your gate or if you have time - browse the shops .
I would be a little nervous though with only 90 minutes , only because some flights are delayed , but so long as your first flight is on time , you will be fine .
You should be ok .
At Heathrow the checks take so long , as you almost have to strip off and the staff are rather slow in my opinion -LRB- nor are they happy folk either ! -RRB-
That is good advice Gen , but my only worry would be going through security checks again , especially if the line ups are long .
Langers , each time I have done it , it has been really fast .
You go in through a back entrance , not the front door .
Each time I have checked my luggage in at the airport in Europe , and it has been checked onto the continuing flight to Australia .
No long lines at all .
Only snag I would see is if you were not traveling on the same airline .
Not sure what happens there .
Mine were British Airways for the Europe flight to London Heathrow then Qantas .
With recent events in the US security has been tightened even further at UK airports and travellers including those transferring have been warned about longer queues and motr checks .
I would ask your travel agent to check the current situation .
London Heathrow is not perfect , but they are better than in the past , especially with BA 's new terminal -LRB- s -RRB- .
