Hi everyone , I have had something come up in regards to booking a hotel room through Insight for 1 day before our tour starts .
I thought it might be good advise for those considering doing the same thing .
We booked a room at the Victoria Park Plaza -LRB- our tour hotel -RRB- in London through Insight , in May for our September tour of Europe .
The cost of our room was a lot cheaper than what we paid through Insight .
It would have been cheaper for us to skip the transfer and pay the hotel ourselves .

Insight should charge only what the current hotel rate is when the room is booked not at a premium rate and also the transfer cost is included in your tour price in London anyways , whether you come a day early or not .
Lesson learned : Next time book my own hotel and not through Insight .
The other day I went onto the hotel site to check on what the rooms were like .
I remember a discussion on the Bulletin Board about this before .
I Emailed Insight and their reasons were 1 .
They book the hotels early in the season and although the hotel might change their rates , Insight does not and 2 .
they include a hotel transfer .
Although I am disappointed in how Insight has handled my problem , I am still looking forward with lots of excitment for our trip in September -LRB- European Explorer -RRB- .
When booking through the tour company , you are quoted a price `` per person '' .
The hotel may charge the same rate `` per room '' .
This is pretty standard .
Maggie May , quote : It would have been cheaper for us to skip the transfer and pay the hotel ourselves .
If you check Insights Terms
As an example , the Dot2Dot transfer service from Heathrow costs about # 21.50 per person -LRB- each way -RRB- .
I always check rates on the internet and with my travel agent and Insight before I book .
At the moment the rates are all over the place which I guess would make it difficult for companies who have to book a long time in advance .
I did have a similar issue in Oslo many years ago and since then I 've looked everywhere I can to find rates .
With tourism taking a hit the last couple of years I would n't hesitate to asking for the `` best '' price available .
Working through your travel agent might get you an additional discount .
On the Easy Pace Russia -LRB- St Petersburg
I also recall remarks about bringing towels
Is that really necessary ?
We will be on the tour in late September so any swimming pools would have to be indoors .
Firstly the hotel in St Petersburgh does not have a swimming pool , whilst the Crowne in Moscow does have an inside pool attached to the health\/spa facilities .
If you are a swimmer and would like to get up earlier or have a swim later then bring a swimsuit .
You may have a stop over on the way home that you need it for .
Also if you decide not to take one of the optionals you may have time , but again , there is a lot to see around the amazing cities and that may be more important to you .
However , the tour is full on .
There are lots of optionals and the free time in between seemed to be taken up with deciding on souvenirs , food or spending lots of time taking photos or enjoying the different surroundings .
We hardly had time to eat we were so busy looking at things or enjoying the optionals .
As to the towels - you wont need towels .
Washclothes are a personal preference .
Bring one if you really like to use it and then you wont need to worry .

Cant recall what was in each room now but I know we used small towels sometimes as clothes or bath mats were necessary in some Scandinavian hotels so the Russian ones are a slight blur in that regard even though it was so recent !
We enjoyed it very much and the tour guides in each of the cities were lovely and extremely knowledgeable about their cities and Russian history and culture .
Have just returned from this tour so these are my thoughts about it :
I am still behind in finishing my diary as well .
Have a fab time and let me know if you want to ask anything else .
Am hoping to post photos and then diary soonish .
We have found that there always are hotels in Europe that do not supply wash cloths -LRB- even upscale ones . -RRB-
We take some J-cloths and leave them behind .
In Europe , what you call a `` wash cloth '' is regarded as a `` personal item '' which the guest brings with them , like a toothbrush .
Hence they are not generally supplied .

In days past you could put medication in the airline fridge to keep cold during flights , this is no longer the case with most airlines .

For those of you with medications to be kept at cool room temperature the choice is very simple , you can now by a gel filled bag that works with tap water and will keep medication cool for 48 hours .
Google insulin travel pack .
These can be bought at large chemist shops in Australia or online .

Now if you need fridge temps for you medication , it gets difficult , however I have found a thermos product called `` Work food and bottle '' that has a wide opening allowing it to be filled with either a frozen gel pack or ice .
I wrap my medication in bubble wrap then pack ice around it .
It will keep your medication cold for about 12 hours .
Its easy to find top up ice at any airport or the airlines will give you more inflight .
BTW you must use the bubble wrap to stop your medication going to freezing point .
A lunch box with freezer packs just would n't work for that situation .
I am writing this in the hope I will save others the days it has taken me to solve this problem .
Hope this helps someone .

I will be leaving for the Easy Pace Italy tour in 2 weeks and have just been notified that we will be staying at the Hotel Sant Elena in Venice .
What was your general opinion of this hotel and how was the location ?
What is the easiest way to get to St. Marks Square ?

ILoveTravel , I have not stayed at this hotel , but if you do n't get any direct information on th BB , you might try tripadvisor.com .
Do a search for the hotel and you will most likely see reviews from ppl who have stayed there and you can map it to see its location relative to SM Square , etc. .
I am sure you will enjoy this tour .
According to their website -LRB- here -RRB- the hotel is a 15 minute walk from San Marco Piazza .

Generally in Venice , there are signs posted on buildings -LRB- usually at the corners -RRB- that provide direction to specific places -LRB- San Marco , Ponte Rialto , the train station , etc. -RRB- so if you look for those signs ON the buildings , and follow them , you should be okay .
Even though the sidewalks and canals are a hodgepodge , if you have a good map and follow the signs , it is easy getting around .

According to the Best Western Premier Hotel Sant ' Elena website , you can also reach St. Mark 's Square in about 5 minutes by vaporetto -LRB- water bus -RRB- thanks to the ACTV stop , which is just 150 metres from the hotel .

jpg -LRB- 288 KB , 8 downloads -RRB- Map
Sant ` Elena itself is a residential and rather green area on the `` fish tail '' of Venice .
There is a vaporetto stop called Sant ` Elena that can get you wherever you might like to go .
That said , much of the magic of Venice is walking the odd little streets and crossing the canals .
Buongiorno ILOVE TRAVEL -
The Sant ` Elena Hotel is an old converted convent with a garden !
I had reservations there 2 years ago , but had to cancel that trip .
I regret not making it there .
I am from Australia , can someone please let me know how I type the country and area code for my home and mobile phone numbers for overseas people to contact me if necessary .

Start with a + which represents the international access code and which varies from country to country then 61 which is the Australian country code , then 3 which is the area code for Melbourne then your number as you would dial in if you were in Melbourne .
Is it the same for mobile numbers
When someone -LRB- or I -RRB- call back to the United States from Europe , we dial 01 -LRB- for US -RRB- , then 513 -LRB- for my area -RRB- then the seven digits for my phone number .
May I weigh in on this ?
I 'm not familiar with a + .
Is that your international designation ?
See you in two months + a few days , Tangata .

September , When dialing internationally you have to first dial the international access code for the country you are ringing form before dialing your home country code , area code then phone number .

The international access code various from country to country -LRB- as Tangata has indicated -RRB- and while you used to have to dial the actual access code for the country that you are ringing from , you can now just dial the + symbol to access it .
This therefor becomes + then your country code then your area code then your phone number .
The standard is 001 which is what you get if you use the + sign , but 008 or 009 will also work and are considerably cheaper .
Of course Skype is even cheaper .
We have a number of access codes in Thailand .
Actually speaking of phone numbers etc. has anyone taken and used their mobile phone in UK or Europe , if so how hard is it to organise it SIM card etc ?
All you have to do is ring your provider and have them turn global roaming on .
We were in 11 countries and the phone would automatically pick up whichever signal it needed .
Stick to texting though .
One short phone call from Prague was $ 80 !
I took my phone .

You can call home from across Europe from 20 top European countries and the USA for 59C per min , With 02 thats the provider I am with , with new EU rules on the cost of Mobile phones when you are Roaming around Europe all the Providers would have to charge around the same just looked it up on My Europe .
And as Laj says dont for get to tell your Provider to turn your Phone on for Roaming .
Thanks for that advice .
I am sure one of our phones has a band which will work in Europe .
Think I might also sign up for Telstra Telecard .
Although it is a $ 1.50 connection fee , the call rate per minute is not too bad eg from Germany $ 0.65 or Hungary $ 1.15 .
Best thing is it is charged to my home account so I will worry about the bill when I get back home .

You may find that some places will still accept Euros , but I would be changing some money over on arrival into each country if it was me -LRB- or withdrawing some from an ATM -RRB- , and just leaving home with Euros on hand and my credit card !
I 'm sure your tour director will be able to advise you of what you might need at the beginning of the tour .
I purchased currencies from my bank branch before my departure and did well .
In tourist areas , I found that shops will often take euros as well as the local currency .
I took the following amount in cash -LRB- for me traveling alone -RRB- as well as having my VISA charge card and bank card for ATM withdrawals -LRB- both of which did not use -RRB- with me :
I paid for the optional excursions with my VISA card .
I had enough cash left at the end of the trip to cover the driver and TD trips as well and converted back leftover cash at the airport when I processed my VAT refund .
FYI , I do n't spend a lot of money on meals so you will need to judge according to your own travel style .

I was wondering now that we did not get the insight bags what size they will allow you to bring on the coach with you ... I have a duffle bag that has wheels ... its not too big but it is long ... I am leaving in 2 days so any advice would be great ...
The dimensions listed on my travel documents are 15 `` x11 `` x7 '' -LRB- 38cmx28cmx18cm -RRB- .
That information should be on your travel vouchers .
Thank you ... I did not receive my documents because my travel agency went out of business without telling me .
I was told by Insight that I do not need my documents .
So I am going blind on a few things ... So thanks for the measurements .
The Insight coaches are nice and roomy on the interior - compared to other tour company coaches .
I had a rather bulky carry-on which I was able to keep at my feet .
As I was about to board the coach each morning , the coach driver would offer to put it in the storage compartments under the bus .
And , every morning I would graciously refuse and take the bag aboard with me so I could access all my `` stuff '' .
While the bag did fit under the seat , it was awkward to open and reach into .
If you are asking because you want to have a larger bag on the bus with you , it should n't be a problem .

If you do n't need anything from the bag during the day , you can take it and put it under the bus before you board and then retrieve it when you arrive at the hotel and carry it to your room yourself .
While Insight will only `` porter '' one bag for you , they are very good about storing a second one under the bus - space permitting .
And on the 2 tours I 've taken with Insight so far , there has always been room for passengers ' extra bags .
-LRB- The overhead racks on European coaches tend to be shallow and have room only for something the size of the Insight bag . -RRB-
The operative word is surely HAND .
the bits and bobs you might need during the day .

and then expect the driver to look after it for them .
Come on fellas ... you are on holiday , not emigrating !

An oyster card will work out the best deal for you depending on how many trips you do , so you do n't need to work it out in advance .
But a London Pass is actually a pass you buy to get you into attractions which you can buy a travelcard with as an extra .
You would need to work out which attractions you wanted to see to make sure this would be worthwhile .
But as for the travelcard add on - it seems to be a pretty good deal assuming you use it to get you to and from Heathrow as it is a Zone 1-6 pass .
But I 'm just reading that a 2 day travelcard is only valid off-peak which is the after 9:30 am rule - so not as good as I first thought .
A single fare from Heathrow to central London would be 4 pounds if paying cash or 3.50 on an oyster card .
You can read up on Oyster cards and the London Pass for more details if you like .
Personally I would go with the Oyster card , but then I would n't be spending only 2 days in London .
My fav city too !
Our travel agent has suggested we only choose a few optionals at the beginning of the E.G. then as the tour goes on book other ones .
What do people who have been on E G. think
ANNE : Most of the tours I 've taken especially with Insight will go over the optionals on the lst night , but will allow you to choose as the tour proceeds to each city .
They seem to find room for last minute decisions .
I had one when the TD needed 36 hrs for a dinner river cruise notice , but as we where leaving the hotel we had a last minute person who wanted to go and had no problem .
At first we only had to pick the first 2 days optionals .
Then we were required to chose all the rest in one go .
Some of the reservations were made a year previous and they needed numbers as soon as possible .
OTher people were on waiting lists for some of them .
When we were up the front , I was listening to the TD making his calls about a tour the following year .
It 's not always possible to add as you go .
There was also the paperwork issue .
All the payment forms were sent in at the same time during the trip .
These are n't saved up and processed at the end .
If people had to drop out -LRB- and some did because of a spreading sickness we had ! -RRB-
it was good to put all the organisational stuff behind us and sit back and enjoy the ride .
We had to pick ours by about day 5 I think .
Teh TD spent a few days going over them .
Makes ense on these longer trips .
they were refunded the amount .
I never saw it as a `` hard word '' .
It was just business , and honestly .
Thanks Frank

It is awkward not knowing what clothing to pack .
We have never done a trip like this before .
Corndale , the usual advice is to take layers .
That way you can be comfortable with hot in the valleys and cool in the mountains .
Take a jacket , umbrella -LRB- get one of the tiny folding ones - you are not always with the bus when the rain starts -RRB- , and sweater .
On our tour of Switzerland in June , the weather varied from 30 degrees -LRB- C -RRB- in Lugano to freezing on the mountain tops .
And take good walking shoes .
In addition , take drip dry undies and shirts -LRB- to wash in the sink on your 2 night stays . -RRB-

We stayed at the Phoenix when we stayed in Copenhagen on the Northern Capitals tour Sept 2007 .
This is not near Tivoli but it is centrally located near the Amalienborg Palace and within walking distance to the canals and old market area .
It is an old hotel with small rooms and the plumbing left something to be desired .
We had to change rooms at 11:00 the first night because the bathroom lights shorted out after my leaky shower .
I would still recommend this hotel however because of the location .
